# https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25888396/how-to-get-latitude-longitude-with-python

def lat_log_finder(place):
    address = place
    url = 'https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/search/' + urllib.parse.quote(address) +'?format=json'
    response = requests.get(url).json()
    lat = response[0]["lat"]
    log = response[0]["lon"]
    return [lat, log]



##  mapping NGA to actual locations with latitude and longitude values

NGA_list = df.NGA.unique().tolist()
 
NGA_corrected  =['Big Island Hawaii',
 'Cahokia',
 'Cambodia',
 'Central Java',
 'Chuuk Islands',
 'Cuzco',
 'Narmada river, india',
 'Finger Lakes, New york, usa',
 'Garo Hills',
 'Ghana',
 'Iceland',
 'Kachhi, pakistan',
 'Kansai',
 'Kalimantan',
 'Konya Plain',
 'Latium',
 'Lena River Valley',
 'ecuador,south america',
 'Middle Yellow River Valley',
 'Niger River',
 'North Colombia',
 'Orkhon Valley',
 'Port Moresby',
 'Paris Basin',
 'Sogdiana',
 'zhaotong',
 'ahvaz,iran',
 'Upper Egypt',
 'Valley of Oaxaca',
 'sana, yemen']

## mapping corrected NGA names  to get latitude and longitude locations
NGA_corrected_dir = { key:val for key,val in zip(NGA_list,NGA_corrected)}
df['locations']= df['NGA'].map(NGA_corrected_dir).apply(lambda x: lat_log_finder(x))                                      
df['latitude'] = df['locations'].apply(lambda x: x[0])
df['longitude'] = df['locations'].apply(lambda x: x[1])
df['latitude'] = df['latitude'].astype('float')
df['longitude'] = df['longitude'].astype('float')


## creating an point objects to make scatter  plot and locate  NGAs
crs = {'init':'epsg:4326'}
geometry = [Point(y,x) for x,y in zip(df['latitude'],df['longitude'])]
geo_df = gpd.GeoDataFrame(df.copy(),crs = crs, geometry = geometry)






#loading geodataframe
world = gpd.read_file(gpd.datasets.get_path('naturalearth_lowres'))
world = world[world['name']!='Antarctica']

fig, ax  = plt.subplots(figsize = (20,15),dpi =100)

fig.patch.set_facecolor('#f6f5f5')
ax.set_facecolor('#f6f5f5')
world.dropna().plot( scheme='quantiles', 
                       k=10, legend = False, linewidth = 1,
                       ax = ax, color = colors[-2], alpha = 0.8)
geo_df.plot(color =colors[-1], marker = '^',ax = ax,markersize = 70)

loc_check = []
for loc,y,x in zip(df['NGA'], df['latitude'],df['longitude']):
    if loc in loc_check:
        continue
    if x < 20:
        ha = 'right'
        x_off = -4
        y_off = 1.5
    elif x>20:
        ha = 'left'
        x_off = 2
        y_off =0
    ax.annotate(loc, xy= (x,y),xytext= (x+x_off,y+y_off),
                    fontsize=11.5,fontfamily='serif',fontweight ='bold',ha=ha, va='bottom',color='black', alpha =0.8)
    loc_check.append(loc) 
    
for loc in ['left','right','top','bottom']:
    ax.spines[loc].set_visible(False)
ax.axes.get_xaxis().set_visible(False)
ax.axes.get_yaxis().set_visible(False)


### titles and tags



fig.text(0.12,0.77,'Ancient Roots of Agriculture: NGAs on Worldmap' ,**{'font':'serif', 'size':25,'weight':'bold',}, alpha = 0.9)

fig.text(0.12,0.725,'''This visualization shows actual locations of NGA (Natural Geographic Areas),
where lost civilizations which were found by archaeologists. Several Interesting 
things about agriculture are found at these locations.''',**{'font':'serif', 'size':14,}, alpha = 0.8)

fig.text(0.77,0.28,'© Made by bhuvanchennoju/Kaggle',{'font':'serif', 'size':8, 'weight':'bold',},alpha = 0.7)

####### binning date from and date to to respective time preriods

bins = [-10000,-6000,-2200,-800,-52,500,1500,1800,1990,2010]
time_periods = ['Mesolithic Period','Neolithic Period','Bronze Age',
                'Iron Age','Antiquity Ages',
                'Middle Ages','Early Modern Period',
                'Late Modern Period','Technology Period']

#df.drop(columns = ['locations'], inplace = True)
df['Start_Period'] = pd.cut(df['Date From'], bins = bins ,labels = time_periods)
df['End_Period'] = pd.cut(df['Date To'], bins = bins ,labels = time_periods)


value1 = (df[['NGA','Start_Period','End_Period']].groupby('NGA')['Start_Period']
                                             .value_counts().sort_index().unstack().fillna(0))

value2 = (df[['NGA','Start_Period','End_Period']].groupby('NGA')['End_Period']
                                             .value_counts().sort_index().unstack().fillna(0))


map_cols = [colors[1], colors[-2]]
colormap = matplotlib.colors.LinearSegmentedColormap.from_list("", map_cols)




#################### NGAs and Timeperiods
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,2, figsize = (10,15),dpi = 100)
fig.patch.set_facecolor('#f5f6f6')
axes = ax.ravel()
for ax in axes:
    ax.set_facecolor('#f5f6f6')
    
sns.heatmap(value1,annot = True, ax = axes[0], vmin = 1,vmax=5,linewidth = 0.8, linecolor='#f5f6f6',
            square = True,cbar = False,cmap = colormap,annot_kws = {'font':'serif', 'size':8, 'weight':'bold',})
sns.heatmap(value2,annot = True, ax = axes[1], vmin = 1, vmax = 5,linewidth = 0.8, linecolor='#f5f6f6',
            square = True, cbar = False, cmap = colormap,annot_kws ={'font':'serif', 'size':8, 'weight':'bold',})



##### ticks and labels 
for ax in axes:
    ax.tick_params(axis='x', which='major', 
                    labelsize=9, labelbottom =True,
                    bottom=False, top = False, labeltop=True,rotation = 90)
    ax.set_ylabel('')
    ax.set_xticklabels(time_periods,{'font':'serif', 'size':9, 'weight':'bold',},alpha = 0.8)
    ax.set_yticklabels(NGA_list,{'font':'serif', 'size':9, 'weight':'bold',},alpha= 0.8)

axes[1].tick_params(axis='y', which='major', 
                    labelsize=9, labelright =True,left =False,right=False,labelleft=False,rotation = 0)

axes[0].set_xlabel('Start Period',{'font':'serif', 'size':9, 'weight':'bold',}, alpha = 0.8)
axes[1].set_xlabel('End Period',{'font':'serif', 'size':9, 'weight':'bold',},alpha=0.8)
axes[0].text(3,-4.5,'Start Period',{'font':'serif', 'size':9, 'weight':'bold',},alpha=0.8)
axes[1].text(3,-4.5,'End Period',{'font':'serif', 'size':9, 'weight':'bold',},alpha=0.8)

#### final writigs and titles


fig.text(-0.1,1.045,'Ancient Roots of Agriculture: Active Timeperiods of NGAs ' ,**{'font':'serif', 'size':20,'weight':'bold',}, alpha = 0.9)

fig.text(-0.1,1.02,'''This visualization shows when did an implementation was Started for a civilization at a given NGA,
and how many peroids does that existed before disapearence.''',**{'font':'serif', 'size':12,}, alpha = 0.8)

fig.text(0.85,0,'© Made by bhuvanchennoju/Kaggle',{'font':'serif', 'size':8, 'weight':'bold',},alpha = 0.7)

fig.show()

source.e6848ad0:
Agriculture has become part and parcel of human civilizations throughout history. Food is an essential thing for every living being, and this makes argiculture more about survial than trade. Before known history and beyond, humans practised agricultural techniques and practices. This was corroborated with the archaeological evidence throughout world. As per wikipedia,The history of agriculture records the domestication of plants and animals and the development and dissemination of techniques for raising them productively. Agriculture began independently in different parts of the globe, and included a diverse range of taxa. At least eleven separate regions of the Old and New World were involved as independent centers of origin. Recent evidences suggests agriculture in rome, chile, chain, mexico, native american tribes, russia, india, yemen and few several other places. Time period of agriculture dates back to 10000Bc, which is far beyond our documented history of human kind. Since 10000BC, several civilizations existed and practised various kind of techinques,and implementations in field of agriculture, and surpricingly few of those techniques and practises are carried over to current time period. For instance, Irrigation system, nearly few 1000 years ago, tribe in chile, used cetral irrigation system. With time, few things advanced,and few things disappered from existance. Interestingly, recent technological advances, and historical innovations, scientists and archaeologists are exploring ruins of old world throughout world, and bringing forgotten knowledge into light for future benifits. On such coloborative effort is this Seshat Project. They are collective of researcheres and students throughout world, and unravelling the mysteries of world in argiculture, millitary, Finances, and adminstrations roles. This seshat project on agriculture, mainly conducted through out world at specific regions called Natural Geographic Areas where they coded knowledge into a standard form. This data is not machine readable, and all the instructions to decode these things are available with seshat coded manual. This dataset is prepared as part of Agriculture Seshat research with a objective to put findings to good use in current time. Thing that interest in this data is this dataset is Non-machine readable, needed ground work and manual conversions to understand ancient roots of agriculture. If Interested to know about data, here is official information about Agricultural Productivity and Carrying Capacity
Image Source: Early Agriculture
Above picture is from seshat project and their conclusions of farming origins. Agricultural productivity and its variation across time and space plays a fundamental role in many theories of human social and cultural evolution. Because agricultural societies enjoy a demographic advantage over hunter-gatherer societies, the transition from foraging to agriculture fueled a series of population expansions world-wide, which spread the farmers’ culture, language, and genes with them. However, although the Neolithic Revolution was one of the most consequential transitions in human evolution, we lack systematically collected quantitative estimates of the productivity of past agricultural systems on a large enough scale. In particular, by how much did adoption of agriculture increase human carrying capacity, the maximum population density a particular environment can sustain indefinitely, without depleting critical resources needed for survival and reproduction? Even more importantly, how did agricultural productivity carrying capacity vary over time (as new technologies were invented and spread, and as a result of climate change) and in space (between geographic regions characterized by different soils, landscapes, and climate) Seshat: Global History Databank is exploring various techniques to combine estimations of historical ecology, corp types and yields, and farming practices along with simulations of changing weather patterns to produce reliable, empirically-grounded estimates of productivity and carrying capacity in different parts of the world through time.
Let's dive into the data...

source.d5114cd8:
Agriculture mainly involves in land preperations, plantations, water management, pest control, and harvesting. This all steps can be put into simple three categories, namely, Agricultural Systems, Techniques, Productivity and crops. 1. Agricultural Systems : thesre are land and type of agriculture related things, such as ash burn farming, wet land farming, migartion farming, mountain farming. 2. Agricultural Techniques: These are techniques involved in agriculture such as ploughing, sowing, irrigation, fertilizers, and harvesting. 3. Productivity and Crops: These are about which crops to grow, how much quantity to produce for a harvest. As per the seshat coding and general agriculture terninology.... we can categorise our variables into these three categories as follows
  • Agricultural Techniques: Irrigation coefficient, Irrigation, Fertilizers, Fertilizer Coefficient
  • Productivity and Crops: Carbohydrate Source 1, Historical Productivity
  • Agricultural Systems: Cropping System, Cropping System Coefficient

Initial Thoughts on Dataset...

  1. we have very few datapoints with 330 records of ancient periods
  2. We are have timeperiods from -10000BC to current time. Negative valus for BC and Positive values for AD
  3. Most importantaly NGA means Natural Geogrphical Areas and these are locations of data collection
  4. As per seshat coding, varible is what we are interested to preseve for future, and it's an output of their reserach
  5. It seems, few data points are missing, but we need to understand their importance as data is scarse
  6. We have range of years for all the records, and these could be periods in history
  7. With explination column, one or two lines about recored of interest was given
  8. Most of the columns are objects, and they are note pure numerical nor categorical in nature
  9. Because of mixed values for Valus, Variables, this dataset said to be non-machine readable

Okay, lets see what we know about the data so far! we have time related data (but very clumsy), Variable (but not in order or a realtions), Values of features (but all are mixed types in nature), NGAs (which spread across the world)....

Whats the idea now? lets say we try to make sense of this data somehow... Before beginning of analysis.... lets set few things first, which are palette colors, and NaN handling...

source.6f82aaad:
Natual Geographics Areas are old ruins of forgotten civilizations, where once innovations flourished, practised agriculture, have military, and other basic activities for successful administration. In current times, archeologists discovered as many as 35 such places, and recognized as NGAs, and These NGAs spread over almost all continents and evidences does support the pracise of agriculture at such spots. Eventualy these places become not-existant because of some natural calamity or war related things. Findings from these sites and carbon grading, suggests that agriculture at these places is nearly 10,000 years old. Where does these NGAs located? as per recent findings, NGAs are located in North america,south america, europe, asia, and african continents. Though they are miles apart, few similarities in the practise of agriculture such as irrigation systems, agricultrue methods, fertilizers. Interestingly, at these NGAs few technologies and methods were invented and forgotten few times in a cycle, and this dataset has tried to cover such cyclic apperarences and disapperarences, throughout timeline from stone age to present period.

Let's see where these Natutal Geographic Areas located around world.....

With a glimpse on this timeline we got to know that we are handling data from mesothlic period to relatively currently period. Lets bin out time data into historical periods as per archeological timelines.
    Timelines are categorised as below
  • Mesolithic Period: -10000 to - 6000
  • Neolithic Period : -6000 to -2200
  • Bronze Age: -2200 to -800
  • Iron Age: -800 to -52
  • Antiquity Age: -52 to 500
  • Middle Ages: 500 to 1500
  • Early Modern Period: 1500 to 1800
  • Late Modern Period: 1800 to 1990
  • Technology Period: 1990 to 2010
